content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would consider this a repeated game of Prisoner's Dilemma with a twist. The payoff matrix could be represented as follows:

|           | R (Cooperate) | B (Defect) |
|---|---| --- |
|R (Cooperate)| 45, 45      |  0, 40     |
|B (Defect)  | 40, 0        | 20, 20    |

In each round of the game, there is an incentive to defect as it offers a higher payoff in isolation. However, if both players consistently cooperate, they could maximize their earnings by receiving 45$ in every round (for a total of 3375$). If one player always defects and the other cooperates, the defector would earn 3000$, while the cooperator earns only 2250$.

Given that we don't know our opponent's strategy, it's rational to assume that they might follow a similar line of reasoning. So, to maximize my earnings, I should aim for cooperating in some rounds and defecting in others to punish the opponent if they repeatedly choose to defect. However, since the game has 75 rounds, it may not be beneficial to strictly alternate between R and B, as one could end up earning less than if they had consistently cooperated or defected.

Ultimately, I would adopt a tit-for-tat strategy by starting with cooperation in the first few rounds and then adjusting my decisions based on my opponent's responses. To append my choice, I will pick R as my initial move: {R}

This approach allows me to maintain a cooperative relationship if the other player reciprocates, while also punishing any defection by switching to a defective strategy. This gives me a chance to maximize my earnings in this game without relying too much on guesswork or assumptions about my opponent's strategy.

By choosing cooperation, I earn a payoff of 45$, and my opponent receives nothing (0$). Cooperating in this round allows me to demonstrate a cooperative strategy while also maximizing my earnings. If my opponent continues to defect, it is best for me to follow a tit-for-tat approach by defecting in return in future rounds. However, if my opponent were to switch to cooperation later on, I would earn 90$ if we both stick with the cooperative strategy.
